Body: Possible Duplicate:  Tablets: What's the difference between the Android 2.1 $169 tablets and the Galaxy at $600+  My local Toys R Us is selling 7" and 10" Elonex eTouch tablets incredibly cheaply at the moment. They're a fraction of the price of a Galaxy Tab and you're buying them outright, not with a contract, in fact the smaller one is cheaper than my Kindle 3 yet have colour touchscreens, how have they managed that?I'd only be looking at a tablet for "sofa-surfing" and perhaps watching the odd movie, etc wouldn't want to use it on the go at all, so don't need a particularly long battery life or 3G.What is lacking on these compared to the Galaxy Tab (for instance as it seems to be the flagship Android tablet at the moment). I have spotted that they're running an older OS version (2.1 for the 10" and 1.6 on the 7") but that doesn't normally stop companies charging a lot for a device.
Title: How are the Elonex eTouch tablets so cheap?

history.Text: My local Toys R Us is selling 7" and 10" [Elonex eTouch tablets][1] incredibly cheaply at the moment. They're a fraction of the price of a Galaxy Tab and you're buying them outright, not with a contract, in fact the smaller one is cheaper than my Kindle 3 yet have colour touchscreens, how have they managed that?I'd only be looking at a tablet for "sofa-surfing" and perhaps watching the odd movie, etc wouldn't want to use it on the go at all, so don't need a particularly long battery life or 3G.What is lacking on these compared to the Galaxy Tab (for instance as it seems to be the flagship Android tablet at the moment). I have spotted that they're running an older OS version (2.1 for the 10" and 1.6 on the 7") but that doesn't normally stop companies charging a lot for a device.  [1]: http://www.elonex.com/products/computing/etouch-tablets-1000et-700et.shtm
How are the Elonex eTouch tablets so cheap?

They're a fraction of the price of a Galaxy Tab and you're buying them outright, not with a contract, in fact the smaller one is cheaper than my Kindle 3 yet have colour touchscreens, how have they managed that?I'd only be looking at a tablet for "sofa-surfing" and perhaps watching the odd movie, etc wouldn't want to use it on the go at all, so don't need a particularly long battery life or 3G.What is lacking on these compared to the Galaxy Tab (for instance as it seems to be the flagship Android tablet at the moment). I have spotted that they're running an older OS version (2.1 for the 10" and 1.6 on the 7") but that doesn't normally stop companies charging a lot for a device.  [1]: http://www.elonex.com/products/computing/etouch-tablets-1000et-700et.shtm
